localizedDescriptions.en: Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial pressure in the systemic circulation.

annotations.comment: Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.
The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the blood pressure measurement.
The position of the individual at the time of measurement.
Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side.   Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.

Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement.  For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.
Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records.
The individual is in the natural state of bodily rest.
The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.
Estimate of the average blood pressure over a 24 hour period.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.
The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the blood pressure measurement.
Additional narrative about the measurement, not captured in other fields.
The position of the individual at the time of measurement.
Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side.   Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.

Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement.  For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.
Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records.
The individual is in the natural state of bodily rest.
The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.
The size of the cuff used for blood pressure measurement.

annotations.comment: Perloff D, Grim C, Flack J, Frohlich ED, Hill M, McDonald M, Morgenstern BZ. Human blood pressure determination by sphygmomanometry. Circulation 1993;88;2460-2470.

localizedDescriptions.en: A cuff used for an adult thigh.
A cuff for adults with larger arms.
A cuff that is standard for an adult.
A cuff used for a small adult.
A cuff that is appropriate for a child or adult with a thin arm.
A cuff used for a neonate, assuming cuff is the appropriate size for maturity and birthweight of the neonate.
Simple body site where blood pressure was measured.
The right arm of the person.
The left arm of the person.
The right thigh of the person.
The left thigh of the person.
The right wrist of the individual.
The left wrist of the individual.
The right ankle of the individual.
The left ankle of the individual.
The individual's dorsum of the foot.
Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery.
Method of measurement of blood pressure.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.
Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.
Formula used to calculate the Mean Arterial Pressure (if recorded in data).
Formula used to calculate the systolic pressure from from mean arterial pressure (if recorded in data).
Formula used to calculate the diastolic pressure from mean arterial pressure (if recorded in data).
Record which Korotkoff sound is used for determining diastolic pressure using auscultative method.
The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.
The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.
Measurement of the electrical activity generated by the heart.

annotations.comment: Also known as an electrocardiograph or EKG.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

annotations.comment: Coding of the ECG type with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: 'Standard ECG'; or '15-lead ECG'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The frequency of atrial electrical contractions across the ECG as a whole (multiple leads).

annotations.comment: Also known as the PP rate. The atrial heart rate is measured from P wave to P wave.

localizedDescriptions.en: The frequency of ventricular electrical contractions across the ECG as a whole (multiple leads).

annotations.comment: Also known as the RR rate, QRS rate or electrical heart rate. The ventricular heart rate is measured from R wave to R wave and calculated across the ECG as a whole (multiple leads).

localizedDescriptions.en: Interval measurement from the onset of the QRS complex to the end of the T wave aacross the ECG as a whole (multiple leads).
Correction applied to the 'QT interval global'.
PR interval measurement across the ECG as a whole (multiple leads).

annotations.comment: The PR interval is measured from onset of P wave to the onset of QRS complex.

localizedDescriptions.en: Duration of QRS complex across the ECG as a whole (multiple leads).

annotations.comment:
The QRS complex is measured from its onset to 
the ST segment onset (J point).

localizedDescriptions.en: The interval between successive R waves across the ECG as a whole (multiple leads).

annotations.comment: The RR interval is measured as the time interval between successive R waves.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results.

annotations.comment: This data element may include a link to the original clinical information provided in the ECG request.

localizedDescriptions.en: Interpretative comment on this ECG result, originating from a device.

annotations.comment: May be multiple. Coding of the interpretation with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: normal sinus rhythm; ischaemic ST-T changes in anterior leads; and/or poor R progression in right precordial leads.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word, phrase or brief description that represents a significant finding in the ECG result.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Normal ECG', 'Equivocal ECG' or 'Abnormal ECG'; 'Spikes from pacemaker signal'; 'ST depression'; or 'Atrial fibrillation'. Coding of the finding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the overall clinical meaning and significance of the ECG result.

annotations.comment: For example: 'posterior AMI' or 'supraventricular tachycardia'. Coding of the diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This diagnosis should be aligned with the narrative in the 'Conclusion'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative synthesis about all of the key findings in the ECG result.

annotations.comment: The conclusion is intended to be a narrative and expanded version of the 'ECG diagnosis'. For example: 'Normal sinus rhythm with ischaemic ST-T changes in anterior leads and poor R progression in right precordial leads; or comparison with previous ECG results.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the ECG result, not captured in other fields.
Average direction of electrical activity during atrial depolarization.

annotations.comment: For example: normal axis or left deviation; or number of degrees.

localizedDescriptions.en: Average direction of electrical activity during atrial depolarization.
Average direction of electrical activity during atrial depolarization.
Average direction of electrical activity during ventricular depolarization.

annotations.comment: For example: normal axis or left deviation; or number of degrees.

localizedDescriptions.en: Average direction of electrical activity during ventricular depolarization.
Average direction of electrical activity during ventricular depolarization.
Average direction of electrical activity during ventricular repolarization.

annotations.comment: For example: normal axis or left deviation; or number of degrees.

localizedDescriptions.en: Average direction of electrical activity during ventricular repolarization.
Average direction of electrical activity during ventricular repolarization.
Lead I is the voltage difference between the left arm electrode and right arm electrode, directed towards the left arm at zero degrees.
Narrative description about the findings for the specified lead.

annotations.comment: For example: ST segment findings.

localizedDescriptions.en: Area of a monophasic P wave or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
Amplitude of the peak-to-peak QRS complex.

annotations.comment: Measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).

localizedDescriptions.en: Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 60 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.

annotations.comment: Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
Value set sourced from DICOM PS3.16 2018 c - Content Mapping Resource -http://dicom.nema.org/medical/dicom/current/output/html/part16.html#sect_CID_3233

localizedDescriptions.en: The ST segment is depressed but not sloping. This is a more specific form of 'ST depression'.
The ST segment is depressed and sloping upward. This is a more specific form of 'ST depression'.
The ST segment is depressed and downsloping. This is a more specific form of 'ST depression'.
Additional narrative about the lead results, not captured in other fields.
Lead II is the voltage difference between the left leg electrode and the right arm electrode, directed towards the left leg at +60 degrees.
Narrative description about the findings for the specified lead.

annotations.comment: For example: ST segment findings.

localizedDescriptions.en: Area of a monophasic P wave or the area of the initial portion of a biphasic P wave.
Area of the terminal portion of a biphasic P wave.
Interval from the onset of the QRS complex to the latest positive peak in the complex, or the latest substantial notch on the latest peak (whichever is later).
Amplitude of the peak-to-peak QRS complex.

annotations.comment: Measured from its onset to the ST segment onset (J point).

localizedDescriptions.en: Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.

Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 60 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.

Lead augmented vector right (aVR) has the positive electrode on the right arm and the negative pole is a combination of the left arm electrode and the left leg electrode. It is directed towards the right arm at -150 degrees.

localizedDescriptions.en: Elevation or depression at the onset (J point) of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression at the midpoint of the ST segment.
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 80 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression of the ST segment 60 ms after the end of the QRS complex (J point).
Elevation or depression at the end of the ST segment.

annotations.comment: Slope is measured in degrees for 25 mm/sec, 1mV/cm scaling.
Value set sourced from DICOM PS3.16 2018 c - Content Mapping Resource -http://dicom.nema.org/medical/dicom/current/output/html/part16.html#sect_CID_3233

The ST segment is depressed and downsloping. This is a more specific form of 'ST depression'.

Additional narrative about the lead results, not captured in other fields.
Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to ECG result.

annotations.comment: For example: Uncooperative patient; difficulty with lead placement; or moist skin.
This free text field could be further coded in a template to enable a Present/Absent value set if required for reporting purposes.

localizedDescriptions.en: The position of the subject at the time of measurement.
Standing at the time of ECG testing.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of ECG testing.
Reclining at the time of ECG testing.
Lying flat at the time of ECG testing.
Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side at the time of ECG testing.
The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying during the ECG. Lying horizontally is considered the 0 degrees position.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents a significant technical quality issue that impacts the ECG result.

annotations.comment: For example: codes from IHE ECG codetable, such as 'Incomplete ECG'; 'Limb electrodes interchanged'; or 'Muscle tremor'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Lead placement for the ECG recording.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Standard 12-lead extended to the right by V5R, V4R, V3R'. Coding of the lead placement with a terminology, such as DICOM CID 3263/ISO 11073 MDC codes, is desirable where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Algorithm used to correct QT interval.
Comment about the interpretation by the device.

annotations.comment: For example: identification of the algorithm used; or description of technical limitations.

localizedDescriptions.en: of a lab test report, including details of the original lab request and associated information
Narrative summary or overview about a patient, specifically from the perspective of a healthcare provider, and with or without associated interpretations.
The summary, assessment, conclusions or evaluation of the clinical findings.

children.name: Imaging examination of a body structure
children.localizedName: Imaging examination of a body structure

localizedNames.en: Imaging examination of a body structure

localizedDescriptions.en: Findings on radiological examination of a specified body structure or region.
Identification of the body structure or region examined.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Liver', 'Right ankle' or 'Lymph node group'. Coding of the body structure with an appropriate terminology, such as SNOMED CT, is recommended. If the body structure has been fully identified in this 'Body structure' element, then the 'Body site' data element and 'Structured body site' SLOT become redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the area of the body under examination.

annotations.comment: For example: a lymph node group (body structure) which found in the 'Right axilla'. Coding of 'Body site' with a terminology, such as SNOMED CT, is desirable. If the body site has been fully identified in the 'Body structure' data element, this data element becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: A physical site on or within the human body that is described in terms of the direction, and optionally the distance, of the site from a central landmark.
Identification of a single direction which represents the 12 o'clock or 0° position on an imaginary circle superimposed over the body site, as seen by the examiner.

annotations.comment: For example: the reference axis is commonly towards the head if examining the breast or detail on a skin lesion; towards the perineum if examining the anus in the lithotomy position; or towards the anterior humeral line if examining the humerus.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identified body site used as a reference point for centre of the imaginary circle.

annotations.comment: For example: the nipple when examining a breast; or the anus when examining haemorrhoids.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the angle of the direction to the physical site relative to the reference direction, either as the position of an hour hand on a clockface or number of degrees.

annotations.comment: For example: the position of haemorrhoids in the anal canal are commonly described at 3 o'clock, 7 o'clock and 11 o'clock. In this situation the perineum is situated at 12 o'clock with patient in the lithotomy position, and regarded as the reference direction. For degrees, positive values are angles in the clockwise direction, while negative values are in the anti-clockwise direction.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the angle of the direction to the physical site relative to the reference direction, either as the position of an hour hand on a clockface or number of degrees.
The body site is located at the one o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the two o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the three o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the four o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the five o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the six o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the seven o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the eight o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the nine o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the ten o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the eleven o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
The body site is located at the twelve o'clock position relative to the identified reference point.
Identification of the angle of the direction to the physical site relative to the reference direction, either as the position of an hour hand on a clockface or number of degrees.
Identification of the angle of the direction to the physical site relative to the reference direction, either as the position of an hour hand on a clockface or number of degrees.
Distance of location from the identified central landmark.
Narrative description that can be used to further refine and support structured data about the circular location.
A media file that is acquired or used as part of the healthcare process, and associated metadata.
Digital representation of the media file.

annotations.comment: If the file is stored locally, the actual content will be captured and stored using the Multimedia data type. For example: RTF or PDF for a document; JPG for an image; MP4 for a video; or WAV for an audio file. If the file is stored at a location outside of the health record, the detailed path to the file is captured using the URI attribute in the Multimedia data type. The Multimedia data type has many RM attributes such as the size of file and URI to an external source - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_multimedia_class.

localizedDescriptions.en: Descriptive name or title for the media file.

annotations.comment: A description of the content of the media file. Use an agreed standardised naming convention, if available. For example: "Right hand burn #1" or "Cardiology video consultation on May 2".

localizedDescriptions.en: Unique ID for the media file.
Unique ID for the media file.
Unique ID for the media file.
Narrative description about the media file.
The date/time, partial date or period when the media file was generated or authored.
The date/time, partial date or period when the media file was generated or authored.
The date/time, partial date or period when the media file was generated or authored.
Additional narrative about the media file not captured in other fields.
Narrative description of the imaging findings observed during this examination.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of all imaging findings for the identified body structure.

annotations.comment: Also referred to as 'Interpretation' or 'Opinion'. For example: 'No abnormality detected' or 'Free fluid present'. Coding of the 'Impression' with a terminology is permitted, if useful. Multiple occurrences allow for more than one coded impression. A narrative description may include a comparison with previous studies of the identified body structure, if appropriate.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the imaging findings of the body structure, not captured in other fields.
